awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Passive Infrared Sensor Technology Solution for Advanced Occupancy Sensing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled solid-state lens integrated with passive infrared (PIR) sensors to detect occupancy.  Today, buildings are equipped with PIR sensors for occupancy detection, owing to their low cost, low energy consumption, wide field of view, and high reliability. Despite these advantages, PIR sensors only detect motion - not stationary occupancy.  By differentially perceiving infrared energy received by standard PIR sensors, the proposed technology may detect moving and stationary occupants.  This may provide a low-cost plug-and-play solution to achieve personalized heating and cooling, identify underutilized spaces to more accurately forecast usage, improve workspaces and reduce operating expense costs. In addition, the proposed technology provides a privacy-reserving solution to monitor sleep quality and fall detection.  The proposed applications include security systems, smart home appliances, traffic management, consumer psychology, and public health. 

This I-Corps project is based on the potential development of a solid-state electronic lens composed of liquid crystal treated with nanoparticles to enable stationary occupancy detection with current passive infrared (PIR) sensors.  The proposed technology is designed to actively perceive and differentiate infrared energy by modulating the transmission rate. Though the occupants are stationary, their thermal signatures, such as body temperature, body shape, and gestures may be perceived differentially by tuning the apertures of the lens.  Using a well-tuned transmission ratio in the long-wave infrared range (8-12µm) where human skin radiates the most energy, the standard PIR sensor may now intelligently perceive infrared thermal signatures of warm subjects in the field of view.  In addition, using an online AI algorithm, the lens is capable of differentiating human from non-human warm subjects by classifying human identification and activities.  Localized environmental information and training data that is collected can reduce computing complexity thereby elevating detection accuracy to high accuracy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Today, buildings are equipped with passive infrared (PIR) sensors for occupancy detection, owing to their low cost, low energy consumption, wide field of view, and high reliability. Despite these advantages, PIR sensors only detect motion, not stationary occupancy. This has long been a plague for applications that demand high-accuracy occupancy detection. Our proprietary PIRvision lens provides a simple solution by differentially perceiving infrared signals radiated by human skin and environmental background using our proprietary explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) algorithms. This electronic lens made of liquid crystal doped with nanoparticles can actively perceive and differentiate infrared energy by modulating the transmission rate. Though the occupants are stationary, their thermal signatures, such as body temperature, body shape, and gestures, can still be perceived differentially by tuning the apertures of our lens.

Though we have well-defined initial products and markets, the I-Corps program will enable us to double down on perfecting and enhancing these features and build our products based on our competitive advantages. We interviewed over one hundred customers through trade shows, workshops, conferences, and integrating with business school course projects. We upgraded our customer segmentation studies. We built connections with early adopters and Fortune 500 companies. We are in discussion with them for leasing reference designs/development boards. We feel very confident in making our 1st business sales soon. The customer surveys center around the potential utilization of the PIRvision lens for PIR sensor-integrated smart thermostats, smart light switches, and home security systems. We have now refined our value proposition and enhance our product features early in the product design cycle through direct customer surveys with end-users and original equipment manufacturers. We also have a clearer understanding how to introduce our solution to our potential customers to reduce expensive real estate costs, identify underutilized spaces to more accurately forecast usage, improve workspaces and reduce operating expense costs. Our solution can also be customized for an array of new cases, including privacy-reserving patient health monitoring, and in areas where lives can be saved--by using our technology for fall detection to allow older people to live independently longer. The technology only has ultra-low power consumption and latency due to processing at the Edge versus in the cloud and operating only when needed. Designed and manufactured in America, our product represents the first technological advance in PIR occupancy sensing in decades.
